title: No permission set on Activities [Android App]

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
Android app version: 1.0.0

Issue Details:
-----------------
The following activities are exported and it does not have a permission set. 

1) com.owncloud.android.ui.activity.FileDisplayActivity
2) com.owncloud.android.ui.activity.ReceiveExternalFilesActivity
3) com.owncloud.android.authentication.AuthenticatorActivity
4) com.owncloud.android.ui.activity.ShareActivity

This could allow any malicious application to initiate the above mentioned activities thus bypassing security checks or getting private information of any user.

Recommendation:
-------------------------
Set the permission for the above mentioned activities or either set android:exported=false (which allows the activities to be launched by only components of the same app or the same uid)

activities.message:
Thanks a lot for reporting this potential issue back to us!

Our security team will take a look at this issue as soon as possible. We will reply to your report within 72 hours, usually much faster. For obvious reasons we'd like to ask you to not disclose this issue to any other party.

Thanks a lot for your report. Much appreciated!

We're considering this a non-issue at the moment because of the fact that an exploitation requires a malicious Android app already to be installed. As per https://nextcloud.com/security/threat-model/ we don't consider this part of our threat model for now.

We'd like to encourage to keep hacking. We're looking forward to your next report!

Your threat model says:

    We do consider attacks involving other Android apps on the device as minimal risk.

I agree the vulnerability requires a minimal user interaction but this vulnerability do have a high impact as it is able to bypass the login mechanism of the app and view the sensitive information of the victim's account.

This is where CSRF, open redirect and phishing attacks come which requires a user interaction and still considered a high risk.

okay let's imagine an attack scenario here:

* I have created an android app and embedded a malicious payload targeting nextcloud users.
* Uploaded this app to the google play store.
* If any nextcloud user downloads this app and install it in its device, the payload will get triggered.
* The attacker gets all the sensitive info from the user's nextcloud account.

Second attack scenario:

* Suppose the attacker steals the victim's mobile (Lost and mobile theft are common these days). 
* The attacker does not need the username and password for the nextcloud account. He can bypass the mechanism because the activities are exported and can view the files of the victim.

Moreover, most of the android related issues require a malicious app to exploit it.

If you still think that this is not an issue at your side, then kindly publicly disclose the issue!

Thanks.

Thanks a lot for your further remarks, we do agree that the scope on this maybe hasn't been prominently enough displayed on the HackerOne page. We have updated this one here, so people don't need to read up on our dedicated security page for that.

The reason we're at the moment excluding malicious third-party applications is the fact that they require a very high level of user interaction to be installed and the architecture of our app is not properly protecting data in these cases.

The Nextcloud Android client can be used to download and upload files to your Nextcloud instance. At the moment files downloaded are simply stored in the public accessible data area of the Android phone. Thus any other app can access the data. There is work on-going for adding a Content Provider though. 

Also, as soon as somebody has physical access to a device one can normally assume that an attacker is able to extract any data. Especially if they're anyways able to sideload arbitrary apps.

> If you still think that this is not an issue at your side, then kindly publicly disclose the issue!

Absolutely. We're happy to disclose any report.
Disclosed on request of the reporter.
